Chapter 5 Compartmental Model Solutions 5.1 Solving with Jacobian Matrices and Eigenvalues 5.2 Routh - Hurwitz Criteria 5.3 Descartes’ Rule of Signs 5.4 Chapter 4 Notes + Linear Algebra Notes

Chapter 5 Compartmental Model Solutions 5.1 Solving with Jacobian Matrices and Eigenvalues 5.1.1 SI and SIR Model \[ \begin{align*} \dot{S} &= F(S,I) \\ \dot{I} &= G(S,I) \\ \dot{S} &= -\beta SI + \alpha R \\ \dot{I} &= \beta SI - \gamma I \\ \dot{R} &= \gamma I - \alpha R \\ \end{align*}\] \[S+I+R=1 \Rightarrow R=1-S-I\] \[\begin{align} \dot{S} &= -\beta SI + \alpha(1-S-I) \\ \dot{I} &= \beta SI - \gamma I \end{align}\] \[J = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{dF}{dS} & \frac{dF}{dI} \\ \frac{dG}{dS} & \frac{dG}{dI}\end{bmatrix}\] \[J = \begin{bmatrix}-\beta I^* - \alpha & -\beta S^*-\alpha \\ \beta I^* & \beta S^* - \gamma\end{bmatrix}\] 5.1.2 Disease Free Equilibria DFE: \[I^* = 0, S^* = 1\] \(det(J_{DFE} - \lambda I) = 0\), Where I = Identity Matrix: Example: \[\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0\end{bmatrix}=I^2\] \[J_{DFE} = \begin{bmatrix}-\alpha & -\beta-\alpha \\ 0 & \beta-\gamma\end{bmatrix}\] \[det(\begin{bmatrix}-\alpha & -\beta-\alpha \\ 0 & \beta-\gamma\end{bmatrix}-\lambda\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0\end{bmatrix})\] Distribute Lambda: \[ det(\begin{bmatrix}-\alpha & -\beta-\alpha \\ 0 & \beta-\gamma\end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}-\lambda & 0 \\ 0 & -\lambda\end{bmatrix})=\] \[\begin{align*} det(\begin{bmatrix}-\alpha-\lambda & -\beta-\alpha \\ 0 & \beta-\gamma-\lambda\end{bmatrix}) \\ det(\begin{bmatrix} A & B \\ C & D\end{bmatrix}) = AD-BC \end{align*}\] So: \[det(\begin{bmatrix}-\alpha-\lambda & -\beta-\alpha \\ 0 & \beta-\gamma-\lambda\end{bmatrix}) = -(\alpha+\lambda)(\beta-\gamma-\lambda)-0=0\] Set Equal to 0: \[ \begin{align*} -(\alpha+\lambda) &= 0 \\ (\beta-\gamma-\lambda) &= 0 \end{align*}\] Eigenvalues are: \[ \begin{align*} \lambda &= -\alpha\\ \lambda &= \beta-\gamma \end{align*}\] An equilibrium is stable if all the eigenvalues of the Jacobian matrix evaluated at the equilibrium have negative real parts. If any eigenvalue is positive, then the equilibrium is unstable. If some eigenvalues are zero and the rest are negative, then stability is inconclusive. \[\lambda_1 = -\alpha < 0\] \[\lambda_2 = \beta - \gamma < 0 \Rightarrow \beta<\gamma \Rightarrow \frac{\beta}{\gamma} = R_0 < 1\] DFE is stable if \(\frac{\beta}{\gamma} = R_0 < 1\) 5.1.3 Endemic Equilibrium \(S^*=\frac{\gamma}{\beta}=1/R_0\) only makes sense if \(R_0>1\). Thus if this equilibrium exists the DFE is unstable. \[\begin{align*} I^* &= \frac{\alpha (1 - \frac{\gamma}{\beta})}{\gamma + \alpha} \\ \dot{S} &= -\beta SI + \alpha(1-S-I) \\ \dot{I} &= \beta SI - \gamma I \end{align*}\] \[\begin{align*} J &= \begin{bmatrix}-\beta I - \alpha & -\beta S-\alpha \\ \beta I & \beta S - \gamma\end{bmatrix} \\ J &= \begin{bmatrix}-\beta I^* - \alpha & -\gamma-\alpha \\ \beta I & 0\end{bmatrix} \end{align*}\] \[ \begin{align*} det(J-\lambda I) = 0 \\ det(\lambda I - J) = 0 \end{align*}\] \[det(\begin{bmatrix}-\beta I* - \alpha -\lambda & -\gamma-\alpha \\ \beta I & -\lambda\end{bmatrix})\] \[(\beta I^* + \alpha + \lambda)\lambda + \beta I^*(\gamma+\alpha) = 0\] Characteristic Equation: \[\lambda^2 + (\beta I^* + \alpha)\lambda + \beta I^*(\gamma+\alpha) = 0\] Where \(a=\lambda^2, b=(\beta I^* + \alpha), c=\beta I^*(\gamma+\alpha)\) \[\lambda^2 + \alpha \left[ \frac{1 - \frac{1}{R_0}}{R_0 + \frac{\alpha}{\beta}} + 1 \right] + \alpha\beta(1-\frac{1}{R_0})=0\] Subsitute a, b, c into quadratic equation: \[\lambda = \frac{-\alpha \left[ \frac{1 - \frac{1}{R_0}}{R_0 + \frac{\alpha}{\beta}} + 1 \right] \pm \sqrt{(\beta I^* + \alpha)^2 - 4\beta I(\gamma+\alpha)}}{2}\] Where \(-\alpha \left[ \frac{1 - \frac{1}{R_0}}{R_0 + \frac{\alpha}{\beta}} + 1 \right]\) is negative due to the signage \[(\beta I^* + \alpha)^2 - 4\beta I(\gamma+\alpha) = \beta^2 (I^*)^2 + \alpha^2 + 2\beta(I^*)^2 - 4\beta I \alpha - 4\beta I \gamma\] \[\lambda = \frac{-(\beta I^*+\alpha) \pm \sqrt{(\beta I^* + \alpha)^2 - 4\beta I(\gamma+\alpha)}}{2}\] \(\lambda = \frac{-b}{2}\) \(\pm\) Complex Number, where \(\frac{-b}{2}\) is a real part. \[ \begin{align*} \lambda &= a \pm bi \\ \lambda_1 &= a + bi \\ \lambda_2 &= a-bi \\ \end{align*}\] \(Z=a+bi\) where \(i=\sqrt{-1}\) and \(a\) and \(b\) are real; \(Re(Z)=\) \(a\) real part of \(Z\), and \(Im(Z)=\) \(b\), imaginary number. \[b^2>b^2-4c>0\] \[\lambda_1=\frac{{-b} + \sqrt{(b^2 - 4c)^2}}{2}<0\] \(\lambda_2=\frac{{-b} - \sqrt{(b^2 - 4c)}}{2}\) where \(b^2>b^2 - 4c\), so \[<\frac{{-b} - \sqrt{b^2}}{2}=0\] Notice \(\pm\), only focus on \(+\) and drop \(- 4\beta I(\gamma+\alpha)\) due to complexity: \[<\frac{-(\beta I^*+\alpha) \pm \sqrt{(\beta I^* + \alpha)^2}}{2}=\frac{-(\beta I^*+\alpha)+{(\beta I^* + \alpha)}}{2}=0\] Both eigenvalues are negative and it is stable. 5.2 Routh - Hurwitz Criteria For stability, it must be shown that the real part of all the eigenvalues is negative. The Routh-Hourwitz Criteria provides a method to check if the eigenvalues are negative and the system is stable without needing to solve for the roots. Instead, the Routh-Herwitz criteria can determine if the eignenvalues are negative by looking at the coefficients. Depending on the degree of the polynomial, the criteria varies. For a quadratic characteristic equation \[c_2\lambda^2 + c_1\lambda + c_0=0\] the coefficients must all be positive. As long as \(c_2\), \(c_1\), and \(c_0\) are positive the eigenvalues will be negative. The quadratic characteristic equation can be used when there are 3 compartments. The SIR model, with the susceptible, infected, and recovered compartment, can be used with the quadratic characteristic equation. For a cubic characteristic equation \[c_3\lambda^3+c_2\lambda^2 + c_1\lambda + c_0=0\] the criteria are slightly more complicated. Here the conditions that must be met are : \[ c_i>0 \\ c_1c_2>c_0c_3 \\ \] And since c_3 = 1, the conditions are therefore: \[ c_i>0 \\ c_1c_2>c_0 \\ \] As long as these conditions are met, it can be found that a cubic characteristic equation has only negative real parts and the system is therefore stable. A cubic characteristic equation can be used for models with 4 compartments such as the SEIR (Susceptible, Exposed, Infected, Recovered) model, SAIR (Susceptible, Asymptomatic, Infected, Recovered) model, and the SIVR(Susceptible, Infected, Vaccinated, Recovered) model. For a quartic characteristic equation \[c_4\lambda^4+ c_3\lambda^3+c_2\lambda^2 + c_1\lambda + c_0=0\] the criteria are further complicated. Here the conditions that must be met are : \[ c_i>0 \\ c_2c_3>c_1c_4 \\ c_1c_2c_3 - c_4c_1^2 > c_0c_3^2 \] As long as these conditions are met, it can be found that a quartic characteristic equation has only negative real parts and the system is therefore stable. 5.3 Descartes’ Rule of Signs \[c_2\lambda^2 + c_1\lambda + c_0 = 0\] 0 sign changes from term to term All terms are positive So there are either 0 positive roots or 2 positive roots \[\begin{align*} c_2(-\lambda)^2+c_1(-\lambda)+c_0=0 \\ c_2\lambda^2-c_1\lambda+c_0=0 \end{align*}\] 2 sign changes from term to term First and last term are positive, while middle term is negative From first to second term, \(+\) to \(-\), first sign change From second to third term, \(-\) to \(+\), second sign change So there are either 2 negative roots or zero negaive roots Cases where there is one sign change: Example: \((-) \rightarrow (+) (+)\)\(\cdots\)\(\lambda \rightarrow\) 1 Positive Root \((-) (-) \rightarrow (+)\)\(\cdots\)\(-\lambda \rightarrow\) 1 Negative Root For \(S(t)\), \(S=\frac{\gamma}{\beta}\) DFE: \(I^*=0\), \(S*=1\) 5.4 Chapter 4 Notes + Linear Algebra Notes \[S(t) =\left[\begin{align*}&\dot{S}= -\beta SI + \alpha I\\&\dot{S}=(-\beta S \gamma)(1-S)\\&\dot{I} = \beta SI - \gamma I\\&J = -\beta(1-S) - (-\beta S + \gamma) = -\beta + \beta S + \beta S - \gamma = 2\beta S - \beta - \gamma\\&J_{DFE} = -\beta(1-1) - (-\beta + \gamma) = \beta - \gamma < 0 \rightarrow \beta < \gamma = R_0 < 1 \\&J_{EE} = 2\beta \left(\frac{\gamma}{\beta}\right) - \beta - \gamma = 2\gamma - \beta - \gamma = \gamma - \beta < 0 \rightarrow 1 < R_0\end{align*} \right]\]
